place.name: CAERLEON
place.gazetteerText: Caerleon, town with ry. sta., Llangattock par., S. Monmouthshire, on river Usk, 2½ miles NE. of Newport and 26 miles NW. of Bristol, pop. 1099; P.O., T.O. It was the Isca Silurum of the Romans, and at a later period a celebrated seat of religion and learning. In an adjacent field is an elliptical cavity called Arthur's Round Table, probably the relic of a Roman amphitheatre. (In 1887, John Bartholomew's Gazetteer of the British Isles)

place.name: CAERLEON ULTRA PONTEM
place.gazetteerText: CAERLEON-ULTRA-PONTEM, a hamlet in Christ-Church parish, Monmouth; on the river Usk, opposite Caerleon, and suburban to that town. (In 1870-72, John Marius Wilson's Imperial Gazetteer of England and Wales)
